verses.text: King Nebuchadnezzar, to all peoples, nations, and languages who dwell on the whole earth: May your peace abound.
verses.comment: Nebuchadnezzar addresses the world, highlighting the global significance of his message. This openness anticipates the universal reach of God's sovereignty, later realized through Christ.

verses.text: It has seemed good to me to declare the signs and wonders that the Most High God has done for me.
verses.comment: Nebuchadnezzar acknowledges God’s intervention, foreshadowing testimonies in the New Testament (e.g., Acts 4:20). The idea of miraculous signs testifying to God's authority runs throughout scripture.

verses.text: How great are His signs, how mighty His wonders! His kingdom is everlasting, and His dominion endures from generation to generation.
verses.comment: The reiteration of God’s eternal kingship parallels later messianic prophecies of Christ’s endless reign (Luke 1:33). This spiritual truth is reflected in the perpetuity and unity of the people of God.

verses.text: I, Nebuchadnezzar, was at ease in my house and flourishing in my palace.
verses.comment: Nebuchadnezzar’s prosperity sets the stage for his coming humbling. The biblical pattern of pride preceding a fall extends through both Old and New Testaments (Prov. 16:18).

verses.text: I saw a dream that frightened me; the thoughts and visions in my mind disturbed me.
verses.comment: God communicates through dreams, a motif found elsewhere (Gen. 41:1; Matt. 2:12). Divine warnings often call for repentance and conversion.

verses.text: So I issued a decree to bring all the wise men of Babylon before me, so they might make known to me the interpretation of the dream.
verses.comment: Nebuchadnezzar seeks human wisdom first—this theme of turning to God’s appointed servants for true interpretation echoes the necessity for approved guardians of divine revelation.

verses.text: Then the magicians, enchanters, Chaldeans, and astrologers came in, and I told them the dream, but they could not make known its interpretation to me.
verses.comment: Worldly wisdom fails to grasp the fullness of divine mysteries. This contrast highlights the unique role of God’s chosen spokespersons throughout biblical history.

verses.text: At last, Daniel came in before me, whose name is Belteshazzar, after the name of my god, and in whom is the spirit of the holy gods. I told him the dream:
verses.comment: Daniel’s reputation as a vessel of God’s Holy Spirit recalls the importance of godly leaders recognized for their sanctity and wisdom.

verses.text: "O Belteshazzar, chief of the magicians, because I know the spirit of the holy gods is in you and no mystery is difficult for you, tell me the visions of my dream that I have seen, and explain its meaning."
verses.comment: Nebuchadnezzar places trust in Daniel, signifying faith in divinely guided authority. Daniel’s role foreshadows the spiritual leadership exercised in subsequent ages by God’s faithful.

verses.text: These were the visions in my mind as I lay on my bed: I saw a tree in the middle of the earth, and its height was great.
verses.comment: The image of the tree may symbolize the human soul or a kingdom’s reach. Tree imagery in scripture often carries both literal and spiritual layers, alluding to the fruitfulness of grace.

verses.text: The tree grew and became strong, its height reached to heaven, and it was visible to the ends of the earth.
verses.comment: The tree’s prominence recalls the ambition of Babel (Gen. 11:4) and contrasts with God’s call to humility and true greatness.

verses.text: Its leaves were beautiful, its fruit abundant, and in it was food for all. The beasts of the field found shade under it, and the birds of the air lived in its branches. All flesh was nourished from it.
verses.comment: The universal reach of the tree anticipates the spiritual unity and provision found in Christ’s Kingdom, where all nations are gathered.

verses.text: I saw in the visions as I lay in bed, and, look, a watcher, a holy one, came down from heaven.
verses.comment: The mention of a 'watcher' implies angelic involvement as agents of God’s plan. The heavenly messenger here underlines divine providence and ongoing oversight.

verses.text: He proclaimed loudly and said: “Cut down the tree and trim its branches; strip off its leaves and scatter its fruit. Let the beasts flee from under it and the birds from its branches.
verses.comment: The fall of the tree is a direct judgment, echoing other biblical warnings about pride. Humbling the mighty leads to spiritual restoration.

verses.text: But leave the stump with its roots in the ground, bound with iron and bronze, among the grass of the field. Let it be wet with the dew of heaven, and let his portion be with the beasts in the grass of the earth.
verses.comment: The preserved stump points to hope of restoration, reminiscent of the remnant theology seen throughout Scripture (Isa. 6:13).

verses.text: Let his mind be changed from a man’s, and let a beast’s mind be given to him; and let seven times pass over him.
verses.comment: Nebuchadnezzar’s humbling is thorough—a transformation reflecting both judgment and the need for conversion of heart.

verses.text: This sentence is by the decree of the watchers, and the command by the holy ones, that the living may know the Most High rules over the kingdoms of men, gives them to whom He wills, and sets over them the lowest of men.
verses.comment: The declaration of divine sovereignty and the elevation of the humble are echoed in Christ’s teachings (Luke 18:14), and in the spiritual hierarchy established for governance and teaching.

verses.text: "This dream I, King Nebuchadnezzar, have seen. Now you, Belteshazzar, declare its interpretation, since all the wise men of my kingdom are not able to make it known to me; but you can, for the spirit of the holy gods is upon you."
verses.comment: Daniel’s unique ability to interpret points to the necessity of authentic spiritual discernment linked to holiness and truth.

verses.text: Then Daniel, whose name was Belteshazzar, was astonished for a moment, and his thoughts troubled him. The king said, "Belteshazzar, do not let the dream or its interpretation trouble you." Belteshazzar answered, "My lord, may the dream be for those who hate you and its interpretation for your enemies!
verses.comment: Daniel’s hesitation reflects a pastoral concern for Nebuchadnezzar’s well-being, reminiscent of the call to care and intercede for others (Rom. 9:1-3).

verses.text: "The tree you saw, which grew and became strong, whose height reached to heaven and was visible to all the earth,
verses.comment: The repetition serves to firmly connect Nebuchadnezzar’s fortune with the tree, re-affirming the lesson of humility.

verses.text: whose leaves were beautiful and fruit abundant, providing food for all, under which the beasts of the field lived and on whose branches the birds of the air dwelt:
verses.comment: The tree’s provision echoes the divine intent for rulers to serve others—a principle seen fulfilled in Christ, who feeds and shelters all who come to Him.

verses.text: It is you, O king, who have grown and become strong. Your greatness has increased and reaches to heaven, and your dominion to the ends of the earth.
verses.comment: Daniel applies the vision directly, indicating accountability of leaders. Monarchical symbolism here anticipates the spiritual kingship of Christ.

verses.text: "And as the king saw a watcher, a holy one, coming down from heaven, saying, ‘Cut down the tree and destroy it, but leave the stump with its roots in the ground, bound with iron and bronze, among the grass of the field, let it be wet with the dew of heaven, and let his portion be with the beasts of the field, until seven times pass over him’,
verses.comment: Daniel restates the vision, emphasizing divine authority in judgment and mercy. Leaving the stump represents continuing hope.

verses.text: this is the interpretation, O king, and this is the decree of the Most High regarding my lord the king:
verses.comment: Daniel explicitly ties prophecy to God’s will, reminiscent of the prophetic authority exercised in both testaments.

verses.text: You shall be driven away from among men, and your dwelling shall be with the beasts of the field. You shall be made to eat grass like an ox and be wet with the dew of heaven, and seven times shall pass over you, until you know that the Most High rules over the kingdom of men and gives it to whom He wills.
verses.comment: Humiliation leads to genuine conversion and acknowledgment of divine authority, a theme central to personal transformation and spiritual growth.

verses.text: As it was commanded to leave the stump with the roots of the tree, your kingdom shall be assured to you after you recognize that Heaven rules.
verses.comment: Restoration follows repentance. This links closely with scriptural ideas of reconciliation and return, as found in Luke 15:18-24.

verses.text: Therefore, O king, let my advice be acceptable to you: Break off your sins by practicing righteousness, and your iniquities by showing mercy to the poor. Perhaps there may be a lengthening of your prosperity.
verses.comment: Repentance is coupled with works of mercy, prefiguring the New Testament's emphasis on faith lived out in actions (James 2:14-17).

verses.text: All this came upon King Nebuchadnezzar.
verses.comment: The fulfillment of prophecy underscores the certainty and reliability of God's Word.

verses.text: At the end of twelve months he was walking on the roof of the royal palace of Babylon.
verses.comment: A year passes before the fulfillment, showing God’s patience and the opportunity He gives for change.

verses.text: And the king declared, "Is not this great Babylon, which I have built by my mighty power as a royal residence and for the glory of my majesty?"
verses.comment: Nebuchadnezzar’s pride stands in contrast to the humility called for in scripture (Prov. 16:18; Phil. 2:5-8), suggesting the spiritual dangers of self-exaltation.

verses.text: While the words were still in the king’s mouth, a voice came from heaven, "O King Nebuchadnezzar, to you it is spoken: The kingdom has departed from you."
verses.comment: The suddenness of judgment is consistent with biblical accounts of divine immediacy in dealing with pride.

verses.text: You shall be driven away from among men, and your dwelling shall be with the beasts of the field. You shall be made to eat grass like an ox, and seven times shall pass over you, until you acknowledge that the Most High rules over the kingdom of men and gives it to whom He wills.
verses.comment: The repetition of the sentence highlights the necessity of submission to God’s will.

verses.text: Immediately what was said about Nebuchadnezzar was fulfilled. He was driven away from among men and ate grass like an ox, and his body was drenched with the dew of heaven until his hair grew like eagles’ feathers and his nails like birds’ claws.
verses.comment: This dramatic humbling reveals a key theme: only after genuine contrition is restoration possible.

verses.text: At the end of those days, I, Nebuchadnezzar, lifted my eyes to heaven, and my reason returned to me; and I blessed the Most High, and praised and honored the One who lives forever. His dominion is everlasting, and His kingdom endures from generation to generation.
verses.comment: The king’s confession highlights the spiritual necessity of recognizing God’s eternal rule, a truth fully revealed in Christ’s kingship and the enduring character of God’s people.
